questions.text: At what time during intrauterine life does the talus ossification center appear? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 months

 

Explanation:

 

According to the 42nd edition of Gray's Anatomy, the correct answer is 6 months.

The talus is the uppermost bone of the foot, articulating with the tibia and fibula above and the calcaneus below. The head of the talus articulates with the navicular bone, which is a boat-shaped bone important for the passage of the dorsalis pedis artery. The navicular bone articulates with the three cuneiforms (medial, intermediate, and lateral) and the first three metatarsals. These bones, along with the medial half of the calcaneus, participate in the medial longitudinal arch of the foot.

 

The 4th and 5th metatarsals, the cuboid bone, and the lateral half of the calcaneus contribute to the lateral longitudinal arch. It is important to note that the phalanges do not participate in the arches of the foot, as demonstrated by the case of New Zealand cricketer Martin Guptill, who had some of his toes amputated without affecting his running and jumping abilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary Ossification centers already present when an infant is born includes -

 

  • Distal femur and Proximal tibia - 7 weeks
  • Humerus - 8 weeks
  • Calcaneus - 3-4th months.
  • Talus – 6th months
  • Cuboid – 9th months

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends.

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh coloured when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: This nematode causes strongyloidiasis and is much smaller and thread-like in appearance compared to Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, this parasite is much smaller and thinner than Ascaris lumbricoides and is primarily found in the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is a hookworm that has a different morphology with a characteristic curved anterior end, and it primarily inhabits the small intestine where it attaches to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.text: Rachitic rosary is seen with which deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is essential for calcium absorption and bone mineralization, and its deficiency leads to impaired bone growth and mineralization, resulting in features like rachitic rosary. The prominence of the costochondral junctions, referred to as rachitic rosary, is due to impaired bone mineralization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily leads to impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily manifests with symptoms such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and impaired wound healing. Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, but it is not associated with rachitic rosary. Vitamin K deficiency does not affect bone mineralization in the same way as Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

 

The hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and intact basement membrane are all suggestive of dysplasia.

 

Dysplasia is characterized by the loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and their architectural orientation.

 

The features of dysplasia include:

 

  • Pleomorphism
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • Increased mitotic figures

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma: In carcinoma, there is the invasion of the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Metaplasia: It refers to the replacement of one cell type with another type. It is almost always associated with tissue damage, repair, and regeneration. The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous.

 

Option D. Hyperplasia: It refers to the increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ. It can be physiologic or pathological. Enlargement of the female breast during pregnancy is physiologic hyperplasia. Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance in the kidneys. In this formula:

 

  • U stands for the Urinary concentration of the substance.
  • V stands for the Urinary volume or urinary flow rate.
  • P stands for the Plasma concentration of the substance.

 

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. The UV/P formula is applied to determine how effectively the kidneys are clearing a particular substance from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration Fraction: This is calculated as the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) divided by the Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This process involves the transfer of substances from the blood into the tubular fluid.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This process involves the movement of substances from the tubular fluid back into the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with multiple patches of hair loss which was associated with itching and scaling. His 2-year-old sister also had similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea capitis

 

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that commonly affects children. It is characterized by multiple patches of hair loss, which are often associated with itching and scaling.

 

The history of a sibling with similar symptoms strongly suggests an infectious cause, which aligns with the diagnosis of tinea capitis. The condition is caused by dermatophyte fungi, and the transmission occurs via direct contact or shared objects, making it contagious, particularly among children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alopecia areata: This condition leads to sudden, patchy hair loss but is not associated with itching, scaling, or being contagious. It is an autoimmune disorder rather than an infection, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: While this condition can cause scalp scaling, it typically does not lead to well-defined patches of hair loss or the contagious spread noted in this case.

 

Option D. Pediculosis capitis: Also known as head lice, this condition causes intense itching but does not result in patchy hair loss or scaling. The primary symptom is the presence of lice and nits (lice eggs) on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea capitis is a contagious fungal infection that presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling, particularly in children, and can spread among family members.

questions.text: Longitudinal growth of a long bone is most likely affected by a fracture involving which of the following regions? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate


The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis (end) and the metaphysis of a long bone. This plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones during childhood and adolescence. Active cell division occurs here, which contributes to the lengthening of the bone. Any damage or fracture at the epiphyseal plate can disrupt this growth process, leading to potential growth abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone but is not directly responsible for bone growth. Fractures here do not significantly impact the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Option B. Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the flared part of the bone between the diaphysis and the epiphyseal plate. Although it plays a role in supporting growth, fractures here do not directly disrupt the longitudinal growth as much as a fracture at the epiphyseal plate would.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the shaft or central part of the long bone. Fractures in the diaphysis typically affect the strength and integrity of the bone but do not interfere with growth lengthwise.

 

Educational Objective:


The epiphyseal plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones, and fractures here can significantly impact this process.

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements: (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
  2. Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
  3. NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
  4. All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3 correct

 

Anticoagulants are indicated for ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation. NOACs are contraindicated in patients with prosthetic valves due to a lack of evidence on their efficacy and safety in this population.

 

Other Options:

 

1. NOACs are not used for moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

4. Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are used for rate control but not universally applicable.

 

Educational Objective:


Anticoagulants are used for ischemic stroke in AF, and NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

This is a typical picture of Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causing pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by 4Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dermatitis (Casal’s Necklace) dementia and Death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pellagra

 

  1. Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  2. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  3. Malabsorption
  4. Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battle sign

 

The image shows Battle's sign.

 

It is retroarticular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

 

Option D: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the photograph:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal Hopkin's endoscope

 

Explanation: 

 

The instrument shown in the photograph is a Nasal Hopkin's endoscope. This endoscope is commonly used in ENT endoscopic procedures to provide a clear and magnified view of the nasal and sinus passages. It consists of a rigid rod lens system that allows visualization of the internal structures during diagnostic and surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frazier's straight suction tube: Frazier's straight suction tube is a different instrument used for suction during surgeries, particularly in nasal surgeries.

 

 

Option C. Atomizer: An atomizer is a device used to convert liquid medication into a fine mist for nasal application.

 

 

Option D. Tilley antral trochar and canula: The Tilley antral trochar and canula are used for procedures such as antral lavage or drainage of the maxillary sinus, particularly in Caldwell-Luc surgeries.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nasal Hopkin's endoscope is a critical tool in ENT endoscopic procedures, providing detailed visualization of nasal and sinus structures for both diagnostic and surgical purposes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient has fever with severe shortness of breath and red currant jelly sputum. On examination, he has altered sensorium with a respiratory rate of 35 breaths/min. Lab investigations show serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL. CXR is done and shows multi-lobar infiltrates. What is correct regarding the management? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ICU management (IV drugs)

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with severe symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia, including fever, severe shortness of breath, red currant jelly sputum, altered sensorium, a high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates on the chest X-ray.

 

The CURB-65 score and IDSA/ATS guidelines for severe community-acquired pneumonia suggest that patients with severe symptoms, especially those meeting major criteria or multiple minor criteria, require intensive care unit (ICU) management.

 

CURB-65 Criteria (score 0-5)

 

  • Confusion
  • Uremia (BUN > 19 mg/dL or Urea >40 mg/dL)
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min
  • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg)
  • Age ≥ 65 years

 

The patient scores high on these criteria due to confusion, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates.

 

IDSA/ATS Criteria for Severe CAP

 

Minor Criteria

 

  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths/min
  • PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 250
  • Multi-lobar infiltrates
  • Confusion/disorientation
  • Uremia (BUN level ≥ 20 mg/dL)
  • Leukopenia (WBC count < 4000 cells/mm3)
  • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000 cells/mm3)
  • Hypothermia (core temperature < 36°C)
  • Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation

 

Major Criteria

 

  • Septic shock requiring vasopressors
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation

 

The patient meets several minor criteria, indicating severe CAP requiring ICU admission and intravenous antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OPD management: Not appropriate for severe symptoms and high CURB-65 score.

 

Option B. IPD management: While necessary, ICU care is more appropriate.

 

Option C. ICU management (oral drugs): IV drugs are required for severe cases in the ICU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with severe community-acquired pneumonia, especially those with altered sensorium, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates, should be managed in the ICU with intravenous antibiotics.

questions.text: In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code for some dehydration is:(FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yellow

 

Explanation:

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines, diarrhea dehydration is classified into three categories:

 

  • No dehydration – Green – Home management
  • Some dehydration – Yellow – PHC based (MO) – 2 out of 4 criteria

 

Four criteria:

 

  1. Restlessness
  2. Irritability
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back slowly

 

  • Severe dehydration – Pink - Is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria:

 

  1. Lethargy
  2. Unconsciousness
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back very slowly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code yellow represents "some dehydration," which is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria: restlessness, irritability, sunken eyes, and skin pinch goes back slowly.

choices.text: Differential mRNA processing

questions.text: Affinity maturation of antibodies is because of? ((INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Somatic hypermutation

 

Option A. Somatic hypermutation: Affinity maturation primarily occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes and spleen. The cause of affinity maturation is Somatic hypermutation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Differential mRNA Processing: This process involves chemical modification of mRNA during mRNA processing. While it is important for generating diversity in certain proteins, it is not directly related to affinity maturation of antibodies.

 

Option C. CD40: CD40 is a co-stimulatory molecule involved in B cell activation. It plays a role in the interaction between B cells and T cells. While it is important for various aspects of immune response, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Option D. Gene Rearrangements: Gene rearrangements, specifically V(D)J recombination, occur during the early development of B cells. This process creates diversity in the variable regions of antibody genes. While important for generating initial antibody diversity, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Affinity maturation is a process by which antibodies undergo modifications to enhance their binding affinity for a specific antigen over time. This is crucial for the adaptive immune system to generate more effective and specific immune responses.

 

Somatic Hypermutation (SHM):

Definition: Somatic hypermutation is a process that introduces point mutations into the variable regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells.

 

Location: It occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs during the B cell response to an antigen.

 

Purpose: The primary goal of somatic hypermutation is to introduce random mutations in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin genes, leading to a diverse set of antibodies with different binding affinities.

 

Outcome: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively favored and survive, while those with lower affinity may undergo apoptosis.

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

Explanation:

 

The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:

 

 

 

  • EEG: The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • EMG: The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • EOG: The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.

 

In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:

 

  • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREM 2: This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.

 

Option B. NREM 3: Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.

 

Option C. NREM 4: Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abreaction

 

This term specifically refers to the process of bringing repressed traumatic experiences to consciousness, accompanied by the appropriate emotional response, often leading to relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catharsis: This is a broader term for the release of emotional tension and can occur without specifically reliving a traumatic event.

 

Option C. Venting out: This generally means expressing feelings, especially of anger or frustration, but doesn't necessarily imply working through repressed trauma.

 

Option D. Guided relaxation: This involves being led (usually verbally) to a state of relaxation, and is not directly related to processing repressed emotions.

 

Therefore, "abreaction" best describes the conscious reliving of a painful, repressed experience and the subsequent emotional discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In abreaction, an attempt is made to bring the unconscious memories and emotions into conscious awareness using hypnosis, medications and other techniques.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

 

The saccule develops from pars inferior.

 

Development of internal ear:

 

  • Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicles or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of the phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Saculus anterior - Not a term typically associated with the development of the ear's structures.

 

Option B. Saculus posterior - Similarly, this is not a recognized term in the developmental anatomy of the ear.

 

Option C. Pars superior - Incorrect, as this part contributes to the development of the semicircular canals and utricle, not the saccule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 13

choices.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is found to have a fibroid of 14 weeks size. She has no specific symptoms. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of an asymptomatic fibroid, intervention is generally not required regardless of the size. The management approach is typically conservative, involving observation and regular monitoring.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop.
  • Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass.
  • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a major surgical procedure and is typically reserved for symptomatic fibroids or when other treatment options have failed or are not suitable.

 

Option B. Myomectomy: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids and is considered for symptomatic patients who wish to preserve their uterus.

 

Option D. Medical management: Medical management is used to manage symptoms and is not necessary for asymptomatic fibroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asymptomatic patients with fibroids, intervention is generally not required. Observation and regular monitoring are appropriate unless symptoms develop, in which case, further management options such as myomectomy or hysterectomy may be considered.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rdedition Pg207

questions.text: In a nuclear family, the oldest person is 67 years old, his wife is 59 years old. They have a son who is 30 years old, and the son’s wife is 27 years old. They also have a grandchild who is 5 years old. Calculate the dependency ratio for the family: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 66%

 

The dependency ratio is a measure used to assess the pressure on the productive population (those typically considered to be of working age, usually between 15 and 65 years old) from the non-productive population (those considered to be dependents, usually below 15 and above 65 years old).

 

DR is also known as Societal Dependency ratio (SDR)

 

The dependency ratio is calculated as:

 

 

In this scenario, the family consists of:

 

  • Dependents: 2 (A child of 5 years old and elderly 67 years old)
  • Working-age individuals (15-65 years): 3 (59 years old wife; 30 year old son and 27 year old Son’s wife)

 

Thus, the dependency ratio is calculated as:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dependency ratio is calculated as the number of dependents (below 15 years and above 65 years) divided by the number of working-age individuals (15-65 years), multiplied by 100.

 

Dependency ratio measures the ‘need for society to provide for its’ younger and older groups’

choices.text: Improves on treatment of thyroid status
Vision loss may be seen in some cases
10% may be euthyroid at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the given image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Improves on treatment of thyroid status

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), as seen in the image, is characterized by features like proptosis and upper eyelid retraction. The condition arises from an antigen-antibody interaction, specifically involving antibodies against thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors, which mistakenly cross-react with extraocular muscle proteins. This interaction leads to inflammation, edema, and subsequent enlargement of the muscle belly, sparing the tendons.

 

The disease process is not directly related to the thyroid hormone status of the patient. Thus, managing the thyroid hormone levels does not directly improve TED. Instead, treatments like steroids and radiation therapy are used to control the inflammation and reduce edema. This is why the statement that TED improves with thyroid status treatment is incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vision loss may be seen in some cases: This statement is correct. In TED, the enlarged extraocular muscles within the confined orbital space can compress the optic nerve, leading to compressive optic neuropathy and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. 10% may be euthyroid at presentation: This is true. Even though TED is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, about 10% of patients can present with normal thyroid hormone levels, or a euthyroid state, because the underlying issue is an immune response rather than hormone levels.

 

Option D. NOSPECS classification is used: Correct. The NOSPECS classification is widely used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, ranging from no signs (Class 0) to sight loss (Class 6). This classification helps in assessing and managing the disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid eye disease is primarily an immune-mediated condition that does not directly improve with the management of thyroid hormone levels; its treatment focuses on controlling inflammation through immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

 

The clinical presentation of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad associated with this condition includes:

 

  1. Intracranial diffuse calcifications
  2. Chorioretinitis
  3. Hydrocephalus

 

These features are clearly visible in the provided imaging, where multiple calcifications (white dots) are seen throughout the brain, which is typical of toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infection in a congenital context typically presents with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse intracranial calcifications. This means the calcifications are primarily located around the brain's ventricles rather than spread diffusely throughout.

 

 

Option C. Zika virus: Zika virus infection can lead to gray matter and white matter calcifications, which are distinct from the diffuse calcifications seen in toxoplasmosis. Zika is also associated with microcephaly and contractures, which are not noted in this case.

 

Option D. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can present with various symptoms such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing impairment, but it is not typically associated with intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to memorize is that the triad of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Remember:

 

  • Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection
  • Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis
  • Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus

questions.text: What is the optimum pressure for VAC? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 100 to 130 mm of Hg

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy, also known as negative pressure wound therapy, is used to promote wound healing by applying controlled negative pressure to the wound area. The optimum pressure for VAC therapy is typically around -125 mm Hg, but a commonly acceptable range is 100 to 130 mm Hg. This pressure range helps to remove exudate, reduce edema, promote granulation tissue formation, and increase local blood flow, thereby enhancing the wound healing process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 70 to 100 mm of Hg: This pressure range is lower than the optimum and may not be as effective in promoting wound healing, as it may not provide sufficient negative pressure to achieve the desired therapeutic effects.

 

Option C. 30 to 50 mm of Hg: This range is far too low to be effective for VAC therapy and would not provide the necessary suction to enhance wound healing.

 

Option D. 10 to 30 mm of Hg: This is significantly below the recommended pressure range and would not contribute effectively to wound management using VAC therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optimum pressure for Vacuum-Assisted Closure therapy is between 100 to 130 mm Hg, with -125 mm Hg being the most commonly used setting to promote effective wound healing.

questions.text: Match the following tumours with their treatment choices: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d

 

 

1. GIANT CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Radiological features: Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with  hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

2. OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic  bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
       
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.
       

3. SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone.
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%.
  • The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

4. OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • The proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive. A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
       
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve. If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

questions.text:
True regarding mitochondrial DNA? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

  1. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome
  2. Single stranded Circular DNA
  3. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
  4. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins
  5. Has around 16,000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, C, E

 

MITOCHONDRIAL DNA         

 

Statement A. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome: mtDNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA due to the lack of introns and protective histone proteins, which help prevent mutations in nuclear DNA.

 

Statement C. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons: mtDNA uses a slightly different genetic code. For example, the codon UGA, which is a stop codon in the universal genetic code, codes for tryptophan in mtDNA. Similarly, AGG and AGA code for arginine in the universal genetic code but are stop codons in mtDNA. AUA codes for isoleucine in the universal genetic code but codes for methionine in mtDNA.

 

 

Statement E. Has around 16,000 base pairs: mtDNA contains approximately 16,000 base pairs and 37 genes, which make up about 1% of the total cellular DNA.

                                   

Other Statements:

 

Statement B. Single stranded Circular DNA: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA is circular but double-stranded.

 

Statement D. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA encodes for only 13 of the 67 proteins required for the electron transport chain (ETC), which is approximately 19% of the total.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA, has a slightly different genetic code, and contains around 16,000 base pairs, encoding for a portion but not all of the proteins required for the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A young female who is sexually active, presented to the OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain, bleeding, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, she had 103 ◦F fever and cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Explanation:

 

A young, sexually active female with features like lower abdominal pain, bleeding and foul-smelling vaginal discharge and signs like fever and cervical motion tenderness, is suggestive of Pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis patient presents with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. But there is no foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option C. Adenomyosis. Adenomyosis patient presents with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and pelvic examination reveals uniformenlargement of the uterus.

 

Option D. Appendicitis: Appendicitis causes migrating pain from umbilical area to right iliac fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A young, sexually active female with features like lower abdominal pain, bleeding and foul-smelling vaginal discharge and signs like fever and cervical motion tenderness, is suggestive of Pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology pg 131-133

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

The concentration of chloride on the luminal side is more when compared to sodium, glucose, and amino acids.

 

In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes thus decreasing their concentrations markedly along the length of the proximal tubule. Thus, the solution will have a higher concentration of chloride which is around 105 mEg/L.

 

In the second half of the proximal tubule, sodium gets re-absorbed along with chloride. Higher chloride (approx. 140meq/L) concentration favors its own diffusion from the lumen into the renal interstitial fluid.

 

Proximal tubule’s high permeability to water, increases water reabsorption thus helps in maintaining sodium concentration and total osmolarity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Their concentration decreases significantly due to nearly complete reabsorption.

 

Option B. Glucose: Similarly, glucose concentration decreases significantly because of active reabsorption.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: Its concentration also decreases due to active reabsorption facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule does not decrease as significantly as amino acids, glucose, and bicarbonate due to the preferential reabsorption of these other solutes in the early segments of the PCT.

questions.text: Identify the histological image below? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transitional epithelium

 

The image above depicts transitional epithelium.

 

  • Transitional epithelium is a specialized type of stratified epithelium found primarily in the urinary system, particularly in the urinary bladder, ureters, and urethra. It is also present in parts of the male reproductive system.
  • This epithelium is unique because it can change its shape and stretch as needed. When the organ it lines, such as the bladder, is empty, the cells appear cuboidal or columnar. As the organ fills, the cells become more flattened (squamous) to accommodate the increased volume.
  • The ability of transitional epithelium to stretch and change shape allows the urinary system to store and expel urine efficiently without damaging the lining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stratified Cuboidal Epithelium:

 

  • Stratified cuboidal epithelium consists of multiple layers of cube-shaped cells. It is relatively rare in the human body and is found in specific locations, such as certain ducts of exocrine glands and parts of the eye's retina.
  • This type of epithelium provides protection and secretion, with the cube-shaped cells in the basal layer and progressively flattened cells toward the surface.

 

Option C. Stratified Squamous Epithelium:

 

Stratified squamous epithelium is one of the most common types of epithelium in the body and can be further classified into two main types: non-keratinized and keratinized.

 

  • Non-keratinized Stratified Squamous Epithelium: This type is found in moist environments, such as the lining of the oral cavity, esophagus, vagina, and anus. It provides protection against abrasion and chemical damage.
  • Keratinized Stratified Squamous Epithelium: This type is found in the epidermis (outermost layer of the skin). It contains layers of cells that produce the protein keratin, which provides waterproofing and protection against environmental factors.

 

Option D. Pseudostratified Columnar Epithelium:

 

  • Pseudostratified columnar epithelium appears to be stratified but is actually composed of a single layer of cells, with their nuclei at varying heights. It is commonly found in the respiratory tract, particularly in the lining of the trachea and bronchi.
  • This type of epithelium has cilia on the surface of its cells, which are important for moving mucus and trapped particles out of the airways. It also contains goblet cells that produce mucus to trap debris and microorganisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transitional epithelium is crucial for the proper function of the urinary system, accommodating fluctuations in volume while protecting underlying tissues from urine’s potential chemical harm.

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 3

 

Explanation:

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3

 

Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.

 

Other tests

 

Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.

 

The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.

 

Test 2: Shows the heat coagulation test. The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with history of consuming polished rice presents with confusion and tingling sensation. He has no edema on examination. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beriberi

 

The patient's presentation strongly suggests beriberi, specifically dry beriberi. The key factors leading to this diagnosis are:

 

  1. Chronic alcoholism, which can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency
  2. Diet consisting of polished rice, which is low in thiamine
  3. Neurological symptoms: confusion and tingling sensation (peripheral neuropathy)
  4. Absence of edema, which distinguishes it from wet beriberi

 

Dry beriberi primarily affects the nervous system, causing peripheral neuropathy and confusion, as seen in this case. The lack of edema is a crucial point in differentiating it from wet beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular system and typically presents with edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pellagra: Incorrect. Pellagra is caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency and typically presents with the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death if untreated. While confusion could be a symptom, the characteristic skin changes and gastrointestinal symptoms are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Phrynoderma: Incorrect. Phrynoderma is a skin condition associated with vitamin A deficiency. It presents with rough, dry skin with follicular hyperkeratosis, which is not mentioned in this patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Psoriasis: Incorrect. Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition affecting the skin, causing red, scaly patches. It is not related to nutritional deficiencies and doesn't explain the neurological symptoms described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcoholism combined with a diet high in polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in dry beriberi characterized by neurological symptoms without edema.

questions.text: Which of the following can result in acute liver failure? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amanita phalloides toxicity

 

Among the given options, Amanita phalloides is the most direct and significant cause of liver damage. The toxins in this mushroom specifically target the liver and can lead to acute liver failure.

 

Amanita phalloides is a type of mushroom, commonly known as the death cap. It contains amatoxins, which are extremely toxic and can cause severe liver damage and failure. Amanita phalloides poisoning is a well-known cause of acute liver failure and is often cited in toxicology as a classic cause of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphate: These are chemicals commonly found in pesticides. They are known more for their neurotoxic effects due to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. They can cause symptoms like pinpoint pupil, increase in secretions, diarrhea, urination and muscle weakness etc. Liver damage is not the primary concern with organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option B. Morphine: This is an opioid analgesic. Its main effects and side effects are on the central nervous system and gastrointestinal system. It can cause respiratory depression, constipation, and dependence, but it is not primarily known for causing liver damage.

 

Option C. Belladonna: Also known as deadly nightshade, contains atropine and scopolamine. These substances can cause anticholinergic syndrome, but they are not typically associated with liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amanita phalloides (death cap mushroom) is a well-known cause of acute liver failure due to its potent hepatotoxic amatoxins, making it a critical toxicological emergency.

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-sense mutation

 

Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Codons mutation: There are specific codons known as "stop codons" that signal the termination of protein synthesis. These stop codons include UAA, UAG, and UGA. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it releases the newly synthesized protein, and protein synthesis comes to an end.

 

Option C. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties.

 

Option D. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein.    

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 396

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Co-trimoxazole only

 

In a patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm presenting with symptoms such as cough and fever, but with a normal chest x-ray, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a likely diagnosis. PCP is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, especially when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/cu.mm.

 

The treatment of choice for PCP is co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). It is essential to start treatment empirically in suspected cases of PCP because delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The dose of co-trimoxazole is typically higher for treating PCP than for prophylaxis.

 

Steroids are indicated in severe cases of PCP to reduce inflammation, specifically if the patient has hypoxemia (PaO2 < 70 mmHg) or an alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient > 35 mmHg. In this scenario, there is no data indicating severe disease, so co-trimoxazole alone is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin: This combination is used for bacterial pneumonia, not PCP. Given the normal chest x-ray and the patient's clinical presentation, bacterial pneumonia is less likely.

 

Option B. Co-trimoxazole + steroids: Steroids are added in severe cases of PCP. However, there is no evidence in this case of severe hypoxemia or an increased A-a gradient to justify the use of steroids along with co-trimoxazole.

 

Option D. Antitubercular treatment: There is no indication from the clinical presentation or the normal chest x-ray that the patient has tuberculosis. Antitubercular treatment is therefore not appropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/cu.mm and presenting with cough and fever but a normal chest x-ray, co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for suspected PCP

 

Note - For a patient with a CD4 count of 200 and lower respiratory tract symptoms:

 

  • PCP Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray is normal or negative.
  • Bacterial Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray shows consolidation or examination reveals bronchial breath sounds.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency room with severe pain in the abdomen. Serum triglyceride level was 1500 mg/dL. Identify the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apo CII

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and extremely elevated triglyceride levels (1500 mg/dL) suggests acute pancreatitis secondary to hypertriglyceridemia, commonly seen in Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia. This condition is characterized by a defect in the lipoprotein lipase (LPL) enzyme or its activator, Apo CII. Apo CII is essential for the activation of LPL, which breaks down triglycerides in the blood. A deficiency or defect in Apo CII prevents this activation, leading to the accumulation of triglycerides and increased risk of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo B 48: This apolipoprotein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons but does not play a role in lipase activation or triglyceride breakdown. Defects in Apo B 48 do not cause elevated triglyceride levels seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Apo B 100: Apo B 100 is critical for the formation of LDL and VLDL particles but does not contribute directly to triglyceride metabolism or cause the acute elevation of triglycerides leading to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. LDL receptor: Defects in LDL receptors are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not triglycerides. It does not contribute to the type of severe hypertriglyceridemia seen in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, presenting with high triglycerides and abdominal pain, is often due to a defect in lipoprotein lipase or its activator, Apo CII.

questions.text: The daughter of a woman who received diethylstilbestrol during her pregnancy is at higher risk for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used.
  • Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions:
    • In girls:
      • T-shaped uterus
      • Cockscomb cervix
      • Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
    • In boys:
      • Micropenis
      • Hypospadias
      • Undescended testes

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer. It arises from the ectocervix, at the squamocolumnar junction. This type of cancer is not specifically associated with DES exposure.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma arises from the endocervix and is not specifically linked to DES exposure.

 

Option D. Sarcoma botryoides: Sarcoma botryoides is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that arises from the cervix. It presents as a pinkish polypoidal growth filling up the vagina completely and causes blood-tinged watery discharge. It is not associated with DES exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DES exposure in utero is specifically associated with an increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg42
